Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Story: The headset presses tight against my ears, the hum of voices and static a constant reminder that every word matters. Lightning flashes outside the tower, and the radar screen blooms with rerouted flights, each one a puzzle piece I must fit into the sky. My fingers fly over the console, coordinating with the next sector, my voice steady even as my heart pounds. In the back of my mind, I remember it’s Sunday—my parents will be waiting for my call. I picture my mother glancing at the clock, my father’s quiet anticipation. They expect to hear my voice, to know I’m safe, to share their week and listen to mine. But the storm won’t wait, and neither will the pilots depending on me. The pressure builds, two worlds pulling at me: the duty to my family, the responsibility to the skies. I glance at my phone, silent and untouched, and feel the ache of being needed in two places at once.
